content.div:
TORONTO - Ed Burns can't sit still. While his body is in Toronto promoting a new video-on-demand deal between Tribeca Films (which represents his latest movie, Newlyweds) and Rogers on Demand, his mind is in an L.A. boardroom, where HBO executives are right this second deciding the fate of 40 - the pilot for Doug Ellin's first post-Entourage series starring Burns as one of four childhood friends dealing with a mid-life crisis. Burns is glued to his well-worn Blackberry, knowing HBO's decision could radically alter the next several years of his life.

"We find out today if HBO picks it up," the actor/director/producer says apologetically. "That's why I keep on checking my email."

While waiting for the news, the 44-year-old movie star is keen to discuss his other passion, filmmaking. He's taking a revolutionary approach to insuring his tiny indie films turn a profit in an age when even blockbuster action films are struggling to break even.

Sixteen years after his independently made film, The Brothers McMullen, came out of nowhere to win the Sundance Grand Jury prize, Burns has, once again, found a way to shake up the industry.

The revelation first came to him in 2008. At the time, Burns was seeking distribution for his film, Purple Violets. But instead of big-figure distribution deals, the Saving Private Ryan star was being offered what is referred to as a "no advance partnership," which guarantees little, if any, cash for his large investment.

Instead of becoming disheartened, Burns gambled on an emerging distribution model.

"ITunes started making films available, so we thought, 'Why don't we release this film exclusively on iTunes and see how we do?'" he recalls. "Seventy-five per cent of the journalists I spoke to in 2008 said, 'You're absolutely crazy; no one is going to watch a movie on their computer, let alone their phone.'"

Luckily for Burns, the media were wrong, and he soon found himself in the company of forward-thinking directors like Steven Soderbergh, who released a number of his films on VOD the same day as they premiered in art-house cinemas.

"I started to recognize that there's got to be a better way to reach your audience," Burns explains, citing the plight of indie-cinema fans not living in art-house meccas like New York or L.A.

For his next film, Nice Guy Johnny - made for a fraction of its predecessor's $150,000 budget - Burns expanded his strategy, releasing the film on digital platforms, including video on demand and X-Box Live.

"We spent not a single cent marketing it, used traditional publicity and social media, and the movie did incredibly well," he boasts. "We thought, 'This is the future!'"

It's a strategy he's continuing to explore with Newlyweds. Instead of at your local cinema, the film can be found right now on Rogers on Demand.

"The audience that loves indie film did not go away; they just stopped going to the theatre," Burns explains. "They're not buying DVDs anymore, because nobody buys DVDs anymore, but they still love these movies. They're at home and they're used to hitting that VOD button, so why not give them the option?"

Burns' strategy is picking up steam. Recently, filmmaker Kevin Smith and comedian Louis C.K. have adopted similar self-distribution methods for their releases.

"The landscape has changed, and you've got to be willing to throw out your LPs and CDs, because the kids aren't listening to that anymore," Burns adds.

Newlyweds is currently available on Rogers on Demand. HBO ultimately passed on 40.
